From Tenuous Beginnings

With the 2011 Rugby World Cup just around the corner, two men in New Zealand - Sam Asfahani and Matt Jeynes - provide the first of their many blogs on the tournament. They start with some of the tournament's greatest ever moments (Thumbnail credit The Opening Ceremony of the 2007 Rugby World Cup, held in France. Image: Jonathan SMITH - Thames Path Online Guide via Flickr Creative Commons)

A missed opportunity: Aston Villa and the O'Neill era

Sean Cole explores life at Aston Villa and argues a chance to push for the top four was missed under the stewardship of Martin O'Neill. (Thumbnail credit The new era at Villa Park is one of consolidation. Image: ell brown via Flickr Creative Commons)

Captain Edwards leads Great Britain & Ireland against America

The Walker Cup is just around the corner and the Great Britain & Irish captain, Nigel Edwards, caught up with Nouse to dissect the upcoming tournament. (Thumbnail credit The leaderboard at the 2009 Walker Cup, who will take the honours this year? Image: John E Kaminski via Flickr Creative Commons)

University Sport at York

Like most universities there are plenty of opportunities to get involved with sport at York (Thumbnail credit Image: Justyn Hardcastle)

College Sport at York

Whilst York may not be a national leader in sport at university level, one thing it does have in its favour is the College Sport system. This gives all students ample opportunity to play meaningful, competitive sport at a level which suits them (Thumbnail credit Image: Peter Iveson)

The Premier League 2011 - Predictions

Predictions are notoriously hard. It's very rare that you end up looking anything else than stupid. Last season the <em>Nouse Sport</em> team had a go at predicting the outcome of the 2010-2011 season and it went fairly well, so we thought we'd give it another go. (Thumbnail credit New hair, new season. Image: joscarfas via Flickr Creative Commons)

How will the return of the Mac go at Royal St George's?

With all eyes on a young man from Northern Ireland coming into the British Open Sam Morgan runs the rule over his competitors and the tricky course that the field will have to combat. (Thumbnail credit The Claret Jug is what Rory McIlroy and Co will be chasing at Royal St Georges via Dan Perry, Flickr Creative Commons )

Liverpool John Moores cricketers win cup final to end York's run

The men's cricket firsts' fine cup run came to an end on a balmy Monday on the 22 Acres as Liverpool John Moores won by 5 wickets to win the BUCS Northern Conference Cup final.

Halifax end season on a high with College Cup glory

Halifax vindicated their favourites tag by beating Derwent 2-0 today to win the College Cup

James make amends for Cup disappointment with Plate success

Goals from Richard Baxter and James Offord were enough to see James firsts win the College Plate, overcoming Derwent seconds 2-1

College Cup Podcast

By James Bithell

Drumroll please, it's the penultimate College Cup Podcast. The semi-finals have been and gone and now it's final time, the <em>Nouse Sport</em> team run the rule over the semi-finals and make a few predictions for what is still to come

Hat-trick from Atherton sees Derwent firsts into the final

A superb hat-trick from Dan Atherton earned Derwent a thumping 4-1 victory over Halifax seconds in today's College Cup semi-final

Changes to College Sport funding brings windfall for JCRCs

York Sport President Sam Asfahani has revealed plans to give JCRCs additional college sport funding to the tune of PS900 per year, with the first instalment to be paid in January, saying "a completely free and accessible system is what we are working towards" (Thumbnail credit New plans means JCRCs will now have more freedom to spend their own money)

The Nouse Sports Awards 2011

By James Bithell

As this year comes to an end we recognise those who have shone in the black and gold; everyone has impressed but some deserve a special mention (Thumbnail credit Photos: Peter Iveson &amp; Justyn Hardcastle)

Halifax one game away from glory after semi-final success

Halifax firsts have had a torturous year of waiting for another crack at the Cup that so many observers thought would already be in their possession come 2011 (Thumbnail credit Vanbrugh's Johnny Grout and Halifax's Jack Beadle battle for possession. Photo: Peter Iveson)

<em>Nouse</em> Sport's College Cup 2011 By Numbers

College Cup team of the tournament

By James Bithell

The Nouse XI who made the difference for their college, and for your fantasy team

Horsfall signs off to signal the end of an era

As I watched my penalty bobble harmlessly wide, probably my last kick of a college football after nine seasons, I couldn't work out whether this was the worst possible end, or perhaps the most fitting (Thumbnail credit Dan Horsfall is the most respected referee in College football. Photo: Peter Iveson)

The Mixer

The Mixer would like to make a heartfelt and profound apology on behalf of some of the other "talent" that scribbles stuff on these hallowed pages (Thumbnail credit "Usually I don't take a bad penalty" - Famous last words. Photo: Pips Ladton)

Late Norton winner puts Derwent seconds through to Plate final

A late rally saw Derwent seconds dump Halifax thirds out of the College plate to reach the final (Thumbnail credit Image credit: Philippa Grafton)

McIlroy unstoppable after 36 at US Open

Rory McIlroy told you everything you needed to know about his demeanour when, last night, after facing the inevitable questions about how he would perform after the Masters he responded with intelligence and maturity (Thumbnail credit Rory McIlroy. Image credit: Zzazazz)

Halifax book their place in the final after victory over Vanbrugh

Halifax Firsts have booked their place in the College Cup final after beating their Vanbrugh counter parts 2-1, thanks to a stunning goal from striker Conor Brennan and a header from Captain Tom Ragan.

Wimbledon 2011: The Contenders

With this year marking the 125th anniversary of the Wimbledon Grand Slam, tennis is as competitive as ever and for the first time in many years there are multiple players who could win both the men's and the women's crown (Thumbnail credit Andy Murray will carry British hopes on his shoulders again this year Image: N Howson via Flickr Creative commons)

Halifax pip Derwent to the post on College Sports Day

On another highly successful inter-college sports day, Halifax again flexed their sporting muscle by besting their collegiate rivals

Baxter the Future for James as they go through to Plate final

James firsts booked their place in the final of the Plate courtesy of braces from James Offord and stand-in captain Richard Baxter

College Cup Podcast

By James Bithell

Going into the penultimate week of the 2011 College Cup the Nouse Sport team look back on the previous week's quarter-finals and discuss what could go on in the last four of both competitions

The Secret Footballer

By James Bithell

Penalties are a grim, unforgiving lottery. I've been involved in a few during my illustrious career in the Hertfordshire Junior leagues, but none come close to one in the College Cup

Halifax overcome stern Wentworth test to book semi-final place

Wentworth gave College Cup favourites Halifax their toughest test this afternoon, but ran out losers to a side that displayed impeccable strength all over the pitch

King Jon Gill dictates play as Vanbrugh seconds win shoot-out

In one of the most dramatic games seen on the JLD in recent times, Vanbrugh seconds managed to snatch a coveted place in the semi-final of the Plate after keeping their cool in the pressure cooker environment of the penalty shootout

All-round performance from Hughes helps York's cricketers to cup final

A fine display with the bat and ball from Joel Hughes earned an understrength York a semi-final victory over the University of Bradford and a shot at BUCS Northern Conference Cup glory in next week's final
